arm_group.description: Participants using an iPhone will download the "waterlogged" application and use this to track daily water intake for 1 week.
Participants using an Android cell phone will download the "water your body" application and use this to track daily water intake for 1 week.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this investigation is to prospectively evaluate the benefit of different
      methods of educating patients regarding their fluid intake through a readily available daily
      cellular phone application to improve overall urine output and reduce risk factors for stone
      recurrence.

clinical_study.brief_title: Fluid Intake Application to Reduce Kidney Stone Risks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. Patients ≥ 18 years old

          2. Seen in urology or nephrology clinic at UNC with a diagnosis of kidney stone

          3. Prior 24-hour urine result with volume less than 2 to 2.5 liters

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. Patient without cellular phone capable of utilizing Android / Apple application

          2. Patient already using some form of monitoring fluid intake / volume

          3. Inability to take fluid by mouth

          4. Patient with urinary diversion, chronic diarrhea, bowel diversion or other forms of
             excessive fluid loss

          5. Inability to obtain informed consent

          6. Non-English speaking

intervention.description: The iPhone application "waterlogged" will be used by participants using and iPhone cellular device. This application will be used to track daily fluid intake for 1 week.
The Android application "water my body" will be used by participants using an Android cellular device. This application will be used to track daily fluid intake for 1 week.

clinical_study.official_title: Do Different Methods of Educating Patients Regarding Fluid Intake Reduce Kidney Stone Risks?

other_outcome.measure: 24-hour urine volume for study participants vs. urine volume for retrospective cohort of previously treated kidney stone patients

overall_official.affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Actual 24-hour urine volume vs. patient perceived urine volume
Ease and interest in monitoring fluid intake based on survey data

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label
